'38','2014-08-08','Government-controlled mortgage companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac posted profits for the April-June period as the housing market continued to recover. Fannie Mae reported Thursday that it earned $3.7 billion in the second quarter; it will pay a dividend of $3.7 billion to the Treasury next month. Freddie Mac posted net income of $1.4 billion for the latest quarter and will pay a dividend of $1.9 billion.'

'79','2014-08-15','State Senator Chris McDaniel asked a Mississippi court on Thursday to declare him the winner of the June 24 Republican runoff against the incumbent, United States Senator Thad Cochran, or order a new election. Mr. McDaniel sued Thursday in state court in his own home of Jones County. The Mississippi Supreme Court will appoint a special judge to handle the case. Certified results of the runoff show Mr. Cochran won by 7,667 votes. But Mr. McDaniel claims that Mississippi Republican officials violated the rights of Republicans by allowing people to vote who did not intend to support the Republican nominee in November.'

'126','2014-08-25','Jayme Beth Frieder joined Simulmedia, New York, in a new post, senior director for sales. She had been director for the advertiser solutions group at Collective, New York.

Bert Hamaoui joined MeringCarson, San Diego, in a new post, group media director. He had been media director at the Los Angeles office of Lowe Campbell Ewald, part of the Lowe & Partners unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

Paul Hornschemeier joined the Ambit Creative Group, Cambridge, Mass., in a new post, creative director. He had most recently been a freelance designer and director and for the last decade was creative director of his own company, Margo Mitchell Media.

David Huehnergarth joined LevLane, Philadelphia, in a new post, senior vice president and director for client engagement. He had been senior vice president for strategy at MRM/McCann, New York, part of the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

Alan Ives joined Wywy as vice president for North America sales and business development, a post created as the company, based in Germany, opened a New York office after its acquisition of Second Screen Networks. Mr. Ives has worked for media companies that include ABC, CBS and Time Inc.

Belle Lenz joined Dentsu Aegis Network Americas, New York, in a new post, regional director for communications. She had been vice president for global communications at IPG Mediabrands, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Dentsu Aegis Network Americas is part of the Dentsu Aegis Network division of Dentsu.

Julie Levin joined Publicis North America, New York, to fill a post, chief marketing officer, that had been vacant almost a year. Ms. Levin had been senior vice president and chief growth officer at the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Publicis North America is part of the Publicis Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe.

Jason Lucas joined Publicis Seattle in a new post, executive vice president and executive creative director. He has worked at agencies that include BBDO, Deep Focus and VML. Publicis Seattle is part of the Publicis North America division of Publicis Worldwide, a unit of the Publicis Groupe.

Shannon McGlothin joined Omelet, Culver City, Calif., as group creative director. He had most recently been the global executive creative director on the Samsung account at Leo Burnett, Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe.

Mark Peters joined the Los Angeles office of TBWA/Chiat/Day as a creative director. He had been senior vice president and creative director at Deutsch L.A., the Los Angeles office of the Deutsch division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. TBWA/Chiat/Day is part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.

Rauxa, Costa Mesa, Calif., named four vice presidents, based in two offices. They are Chelsea Hunter, vice president for account services, in San Francisco; Annie June, vice president for account services, in New York; Patrick Lopez, vice president for strategic insights, in New York; and Lindy Roux, vice president for content marketing and strategy, in San Francisco.

Doug Scott joined WME/IMG in a new post, executive vice president for marketing and brand solutions, based in New York. He had been president of OgilvyEntertainment, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide division of WPP.

Ellie Taylor joined Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, in a new post, communications and marketing director. She had been an account director at Martin Williams, Minneapolis, part of the Omnicom Group.

Alex Vlasto joined the New York office of Lotame in a new post, senior vice president for marketing. He had been vice president for marketing and communications at Undertone, New York.

Tania Weinkle joined the Anaheim/Orange County Visitor and Convention Bureau, Anaheim, Calif., as communications director. She had most recently been director for public relations at Innocean USA, Huntington Beach, Calif., part of Innocean.'

'131','2014-08-26','On the third deuce of the 5-5 game, Kyrgios hit a spectacular runaround forehand winner that sparked his game and the crowd, and led to the first break of the match. Kyrgios led by 40-0 serving at 6-5 and surprisingly double-faulted twice before forcing a backhand return error at 40-30 to seal the set.

Kyrgios broke Youzhny in the opening game of the second set and served consecutive aces in the next game to consolidate the break. He led, 4-2, and it was almost going too easily. The hot conditions looked as if they were taking a toll on Youzhny as he threw in an 87-mile-per-hour first serve in the 2-4 game.

Just when it felt very comfortable, Kyrgios got loose. He played his first bad service game serving at 4-3 in the second set, missing a short forehand to lose the game and his composure. As soon as he missed the forehand on break point, he took a ball from his pocket and launched it out of the stadium.

Kyrgios held things together well enough to reach the tiebreaker and raced to a 5-1 lead before winning, 7-4. He led two sets to love, but a disastrous third set was looming.

He was broken in the opening game of the third set and was clearly frustrated at the dogged ad court tactics of Youzhny, the errors that were piling up, and an injury to his left arm, which forced him to withdraw from the Cincinnati Masters two weeks ago. Trailing by 2-4 in the third, Kyrgios lost his service game at love with almost no opposition.

Kyrgios was broken relatively easily at the beginning of the fourth set, and his attitude went south. He was penalized a game for bad language. He responded by hitting two angry aces and two unreturned serves in the next game at 1-3. Kyrgios finally broke back for 5-5 with a backhand winner on break point and got his emotions under control, losing only one point in the fourth-set tiebreaker.

He hit 68 winners for the match with 26 aces and 22 forehand winners. Kyrgios hit 277 forehands for the match and 214 backhands, but the forehands flowed much more freely toward the end.

Kyrgios will play the 49th-ranked Andreas Seppi of Italy in the second round.'

'138','2014-08-27','Pinch-hitter Ike Davis blasted a tiebreaking, three-run homer off Seth Maness in the eighth inning Tuesday night, lifting the Pittsburgh Pirates over the visiting St. Louis Cardinals, 5-2.

The Pirates won after Andrew McCutchen left in the fifth inning because of discomfort in his left ribs. Recently on the disabled list because of a rib problem, McCutchen ran into the wall earlier in the game.

Davis sent a 2-2 pitch from Maness deep over the fence in right-center for his ninth home run of the season and his third as a pinch-hitter.

ORIOLES 4, RAYS 2 Jonathan Schoop singled in the go-ahead run in the sixth inning and Caleb Joseph had two runs batted in as host Baltimore beat fading Tampa Bay. The Rays have lost seven of 10 since reaching the .500 mark on Aug. 15.

PHILLIES 3, NATIONALS 2 Freddy Galvis and Darin Ruf homered and Carlos Ruiz drove in the go-ahead run with an eighth-inning sacrifice fly to lead host Philadelphia to a victory over Washington.'

'147','2014-08-28','1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Oil an oven-proof, lidded casserole or Dutch oven large enough to accommodate all of the peppers. In a large bowl, mix farro, cheese, walnuts, tomatoes and paprika. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

2. Cut tops away from peppers and gently remove seeds and membranes. Season the insides with a little salt, then fill with farro mix. Sprinkle a little paprika over the top and replace tops of peppers. Place upright in the casserole.

3. Mix water, lemon juice, salt to taste, tomato paste and olive oil and pour into the casserole. Place in the oven and bake 30 to 40 minutes, until peppers are tender. Remove from the heat and allow to cool slightly in the casserole. Remove tops and spoon liquid from the casserole over the filling. Serve warm or at room temperature.

Alternative method: You can also cook these on top of the stove. Bring to a simmer, cover and simmer over low heat for 30 to 40 minutes.

Advance preparation: The filling as well as the stuffed peppers will keep for 3 days in the refrigerator. Cooked farro and spelt keep for 3 days in the refrigerator and freeze well.

Nutritional information per serving: 216 calories; 10 grams fat; 4 grams saturated fat; 3 grams polyunsaturated fat; 3 grams monounsaturated fat; 10 milligrams cholesterol; 25 grams carbohydrates; 5 grams dietary fiber; 125 milligrams sodium (does not include salt to taste); 9 grams protein'
